SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: Debate over rebel flag widens to include all symbols of Confederacy
The debate over the rebel flag that began anew after last week's church shootings in Charleston, S.C., has morphed into a full-blown Confederate controversy.

While Stars and Bars have long been associated by many with slavery, the latest campaign to remove Confederate emblems has extended beyond the flag to statues, memorials, parks and even school mascots. Never has the debate over what symbolizes heritage and what stands for hate covered so much ground, as efforts to strip icons that have been part of the visual and cultural landscape of the South for decades are afoot at national, state and local levels.
In one Arkansas town, the school board voted unanimously Tuesday to ban the song "Dixie" for the next school year and phase out “Rebel,” the school’s mascot.

I'm from the Southwest, not the South, so when I visited Austin I was flabbergasted at seeing all the statues of confederate statesmen and generals. I am a bit of a amateur historian, I know what these guys did, what they were fighting for. Frankly I was shocked that they were being revered the way they were.

You know, here's the thing. For several decades, the majority of Whites have believed that there is little to no racism left in this country, while the majority of Blacks have continued to notice racism just about everywhere. Now, racism isn't as rampant as some would have you believe, but neither is it as minimal as we delude ourselves into it being, either. There are some who believe that all Whites, as a result of our race, are racists - not by intent of being racist, but by accepting (and expecting) the priviledges that are given to us by being White. And there's been study after study that show, that deep down, we're almost all racist, as most of us are more likely to see a Black man as being more dangerous than a White man. And this also goes for most of us who don't consider ourselves racist at all! So, no, removing these symbols of the Confederacy (most of which most people don't even know are symbols of the Confederacy) won't help much.

What needs to happen, though, is discussion. Frank discussion. Discussion about police violence, gang violence, bank policies, hiring decisions, fears, poverty (a lot of so-called racial issues are actually poverty issues, but people of color are more likely to be in poverty than Whites), incarceration (and punishments, period - for the same crime, are there differences in sentencing correllated to race?), weapons (people in the inner city are much more likely to support gun control; people in the suburbs and rural areas are much more likely to be against it), and a vast plethora of other topics that most of us Whites would have no idea have racial undertones, but actually seem to for people of color. And this needs to happen in every corner of the country. And all involved need to be willing to actually listen - to truths that will make us feel uncomfortable, at best.

A frank discussion alright is needed, not one plantation owner was a Republican. I don't think we will see that discussion come. <img src="images/smilies/frown.gif" border="0" alt="" title="Frown" class="inlineimg">

A frank discussion alright is needed, not one plantation owner was a Republican. I don't think we will see that discussion come. <img src="images/smilies/frown.gif" border="0" alt="" title="Frown" class="inlineimg">

That's a given. But - most of the "Dixiecrats" (Southern Democrats) eventually joined the Republican Party between the 1940s and 1970s. Seriously - starting in 1860, the Dems in the North and the Dems in the South were pretty much two separate political parties for over a hundred years. During this time, in the North, the Dems stood for farmers, labor & unions. In the South, the Dems stood for racism and segregation. When the Northern Dems started to gain the upper hand and power in the party, the Southern Dems eventually revolted - finally solidifying themselves to the GOP during Nixon's "Southern strategy".

Someone made an observation that ISIS seems to destroy images, the Taliban destroyed images. I'm not sure if this is a good analogy but it does make one think. Jefferson Memorial?
I am a black South Carolinian. Here’s why I support the Confederate flag.
I hang the Confederate flag in my home. But that doesn't mean it should fly over our statehouse.

Four years ago, I became a national news story after I hung a Confederate flag in my dorm room window at the University of South Carolina Beaufort. Controversy wasn’t my intention. For me and many Southerners, the flag celebrates my heritage and regional pride. One of my ancestors, Benjamin Thomas, was a black Confederate cook, and I do not want to turn my back on his service to the South. So I hang the flag in honor of his hard work and dedication to South Carolina during the Civil War.

My Confederate flag isn’t racist; after all, I am black. I’m also an American who strongly believes in the constitutional right to free speech. I fought back against the university’s demand that I take my flag down simply because others view it as a symbol of racism. I fought back against the racist interpretation of the flag and I won.

Firstly, can someone explain "white privilege" to me? Because like, nothing has been handed to me. I grew up in a rural town, where it is close to 50/50 black/white. Most of us weren't poor, but more towards lower middle class. Only a few of us we're upper middle class. Actually, looking back, there seemed to be more poor whites, this is just based on clothes/shoes that people wore. Seemed like more whites had wore out shoes and pants that were too short.
When I got in trouble, I went to the farm to work. I have literally picked cotton in a field. I don't think many of my black friends growing up can say that. That mess hurts, btw.
How exactly am I more privileged? What can I do that blacks can't? There are blacks who have PhDs and whites flipping burgers.

*Disclaimer* Totally not a racist. Ex-husband is black. I literally have more black friends than white and I have never heard them say or act that I have privileges that they don't. I'm just Kendra. <img src="images/smilies/shrug.gif" border="0" alt="" title="Shrug" class="inlineimg">

Also, what is next? Changing county and city names that were named after Confederate military leaders? Forrest Gump can't be on TV anymore because he was named after General Nathan Bedford Forrest? Kappa Alpha order can't have General Lee as a "Spiritual Founder" because of his chivalry and gentlemanly conduct? Kappa Sigma will have to remove Jefferson Davis as an honorary member? Where will this end? When all of any history of what happened is gone? That's not good. You can't forget where you came from and you can't brush it under the rug.

I agree with you; removing from the SC statehouse a flag which is consciously used as a racist symbol by white supremacists is one thing, cutting 'Dixie' from band practice is just stupid (I suppose no one should play the 'Ride of of the Valkyries' either because Wagner was a favourite composer of Hitler...)

With regards white privilege, it doesn't mean that any one white person themselves has a privileged economic (or whatever) status, or that black people can't get PhDs (or become President for that matter!); it means that even without anyone being consciously racist, white people tend to have an easier time. If you, Kendra, were stopped by the police and they found cocaine in your car, you are statistically much less likely to get jail time than you would if you were black, for the same quantity of drugs - that's an example of white privilege. This isn't remotely something unique to the US as the same thing happens here in the UK.

How people decorate their homes is up to them, but the South lost the Civil War. Therefore, I think the US flag should be flown at all government buildings, public parks. Every place that's public and not private.
I was going write an inflammatory post as to why I hate the flag of treason, but I'll refrain from doing so.
In the end I'm stuck between defending filthy hippies who would burn the American flag just the same as the Confederate rag. And Anti-American Neo-Confederates. A rock and a hard place for sure.
I will say its silly to have statues of Lee and Jackson, its like honoring Benedict Arnold.

How people decorate their homes is up to them, but the South lost the Civil War. Therefore, I think the US flag should be flown at all government buildings, public parks. Every place that's public and not private.
The US flag is flown in the south. It isn't like we hate the country we live in. Most are very patriotic. Lots even join the military. But the culture is different down here, that's for sure.
I completely agree that the Confederate battle flag shouldn't be flown over a state capitol -- that should be the current flag, representing all the state's citizens.
But this whole thing has gone insane. Pretty soon we'll have to pretend the Civil War never happened.
